content: <collection xmlns="http://www.loc.gov/MARC21/slim"> <record>   <controlfield tag="001">7451</controlfield>   <controlfield tag="005">20140310183757.0</controlfield>   <datafield tag="711" ind1=" " ind2=" ">     <subfield code="c">Barcelona, Spain</subfield>     <subfield code="a">IEEE 8th International Conference on Wireless and Mobile Computing, Networking and Communications</subfield>     <subfield code="g">WiMob 2012</subfield>     <subfield code="d">October 2012</subfield>   </datafield>   <datafield tag="536" ind1=" " ind2=" ">     <subfield code="c">288535</subfield>     <subfield code="a">CONFINE - Community Networks Testbed for the Future Internet (288535)</subfield>   </datafield>   <datafield tag="653" ind1="1" ind2=" ">     <subfield code="a">community networks</subfield>   </datafield>   <datafield tag="653" ind1="1" ind2=" ">     <subfield code="a">OMF</subfield>   </datafield>   <datafield tag="653" ind1="1" ind2=" ">     <subfield code="a">CONFINE</subfield>   </datafield>   <datafield tag="653" ind1="1" ind2=" ">     <subfield code="a">overhead</subfield>   </datafield>   <datafield tag="245" ind1=" " ind2=" ">     <subfield code="a">Overhead Analysis of Embedded Wireless Testbeds</subfield>   </datafield>   <datafield tag="542" ind1=" " ind2=" ">     <subfield code="l">open</subfield>   </datafield>   <datafield tag="520" ind1=" " ind2=" ">     <subfield code="a"><p>As community networks are being deployed more often, interest in using them as testbeds is growing too. Frameworks like the cOntrol and Management Framework (OMF) are helpful software tools to organize, control and instrument the testbeds deployed on those networks. However, community networks have a very heterogeneous infrastructure in which less powerful, embedded devices will play an important role due to their low cost. This work will analyze the overhead generated by the OMF framework when deployed on embedded devices. Possible performance hits introduced by the overhead on both desktop and embedded systems will be presented and compared.&nbsp;</p></subfield>   </datafield>   <datafield tag="100" ind1=" " ind2=" ">     <subfield code="u">University of Antwerp - IBBT</subfield>     <subfield code="a">Nathan Samson</subfield>   </datafield>   <datafield tag="700" ind1=" " ind2=" ">     <subfield code="u">University
